bibl.title: Letter from W. Edwin Hemphill to Philip Showalter Hench, October 30, 1951

div1.p: Hemphill thanks Hench for his comments on the manuscript about Reed's years in Virginia. He would like copies of Hench's photographs of Reed's University of Virginia medical diploma and of his birthplace.

div1.head: Letter from W. Edwin Hemphill to Philip Showalter Hench, October 30, 1951
div1.opener:
COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA
VIRGINIA
PERSEVERANDO
GENERAL LIBRARY DIVISION
ARCHIVES DIVISION
LAND OFFICE
EXTENSION DIVISION
PUBLICATIONS DIVISION
HISTORY DIVISION
RANDOLPH W. CHURCH
STATE LIBRARIAN
RAY O. HUMMEL, JR.
ASSISTANT LIBRARIAN
VIRGINIA STATE LIBRARY
RICHMOND 19
October 30, 1951
Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
My colleagues and I are indeed grateful to you for your
informative letter of October 26 concerning our proposed
article for Virginia Cavalcade on the period of Walter Reed's
life during which he resided in Virginia. Your comments are
quite helpful, particularly your paragraph in which you dis-
cuss Reed's alleged challenge to a member of the faculty of
the University of Virginia. We are going to modify slightly
our words in respect to that incident, though the article is
already now in galley proof. I assure you that my colleague
who wrote the manuscript, Mr. James H. Bailey, had consulted
the biography by Laura Wood and the pamphlet issued by the
Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. He has also been inter-
ested in reading the reprint by Dr. Arthur C. Jacobson, though
of course it deals with a period of Reed's life shortly after
that which we propose to cover. This reprint is being re-
turned, as you requested, herewith.

I shall appreciate your sending or having sent to me as
promptly as you possibly can a picture of the medical diploma
awarded to Walter Reed by the University of Virginia and at
least the two best of your pictures of the birthplace of Walter
Reed, showing the spot before and after the dwelling was re-
stored. These pictures should be sent to me, if possible, in
the form of a glossy print, preferably 8" x 10" in size. If
you incur any expense whatsoever in obtaining such prints,
please have your photographer send us an official invoice or
bill for them and for the postal expense. If you are willing
to lend to us any of your originals of these pictures, we can
pledge that they will be handled carefully and returned safely
after we have had a short while to have our engraver work on
Dr. Philip S. Hench
October 30, 1951
Page 2
them or to have our photographer duplicate them.

I am acting upon your suggestions in regard to pictures
from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and from the
United States Army Medical Museum, though the latter seem to
be beyond our period of Reed's life.

We are indeed grateful to you for your cooperation. I
look forward to seeing your brother on Thursday of this week,
when I am to address the Albemarle County Historical Society.
I will inquire of him then about the academy and the Reed house
in Charlottesville.
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, W. Edwin Hemphill, Head
History Division WEH/eh
Encl.
